note.p: University of Chicago 1380, Chicago, IL. Paris, late 14th century
Parchment, 265 x 180 mm, 171 folios (10 additional paper leaves in a second booklet)
Parchment somewhat wrinkled and soiled, but in solid condition. One repair to a missing corner on fol. 6.

list.head: Collation:
list.item: 1-6 (2 leaves wanting between fols. 3 and 4 (i.e. the inner most bifolium); Lecoy ll. 377-617)
7-12 (2 leaves wanting, one each after fols. 6 and 11; Lecoy 1017-1133 and 1815-1944)

note.p: * The gathering of six leaves plus a bifolium found in quires XXII-XXIII is unusual; perhaps this happened when the book was rebound in 1907. The evidence is very difficult to see, and it is possible that these two together constitute one gathering of eight.

v+171+10+v. A few signatures survive on gatherings II-IV, and a few catchwords at 12v, 20v, and 28v. Modern foliation, top right of rectos, in ink, is accurate. An earlier pagination in pencil, most clearly visible in the paper booklet, remains, much of it erased.

Ruled in red crayon. A few prickings remain visible along the lower edge of the manuscript, especially in quire VI, but most have been cropped away. Fols. 1r-141r, i.e. Roman de la Rose, ruled for two columns of 39 lines each. Three horizontal through lines, one at the top, and two closely spaced at the bottom. Six vertical through lines, one defining each side of the two columns, and another in each column to delineate the first letter of each line. The Testament, fols. 142r-170r, q ruled with same number and placement of horizontal through lines, but for one large text block of 39 lines, with four vertical through lines – one defining each side of the text block, and two to the right of each initial. Fol. 170v, containing the end of Le Codicille, ruled as 1r-141r but for 38 lines. Paper booklet, fols. 172-181, ruled very simply with single vertical line on either edge of the text block. Fols. 1-170, text blocks 215 x 150 mm; for Roman de la Rose each column 65 mm wide. Text block varies in paper booklet, but approximately 230 x 100 mm.

One scribe, using textualis script, throughout fols. 1-141. Paper booklet contains two late 16th- or early 17th-century cursive hands. A variety of corrections may be found throughout, including erasure and overwriting (numerous examples 116v-118r) and lining through (e.g. 63r, 125r). Numerous examples of single lines (e.g. 32v) and couplets (e.g. 36r) added later in several different hands. Text is also added in an extended column at 65r and in a large block in the lower margins of 100v-101r, although much of the latter is lost to cropping. Lines found to be out of order by later readers are corrected with marginal notations of “a” and “b” to show their proper order (e.g. 38r, 60v).

Numerous rubricated lines throughout. If not otherwise ornamented, the first letter of each line is touched in yellow, now badly faded – see, e.g., 61v-62r, where these are still visible. A six-line initial with vinework on 1r; blue letter with white tracery and gold, blue, and red vine decoration. Numerous two-line initials throughout, alternating gold initials with blue penwork decoration and blue initials with red penwork decoration. A single historiated initial, 10 lines in height, at the beginning of the Testament. Borders on 1r and 142r – gold, red, and blue borders with vines and buds in same color scheme.

Bound in 1907 by Katharine Adams at Broadway, Worcestershire. Binding 275 mm in height, 215 mm from center of spine to fore edge. Red leather, probably sheepskin (although Cockerell’s inscription on flyleaf identifies it as pigskin), over pasteboard. Five raised bands on spine. Headbands and tailbands of green thread, probably same thread visible at center of gatherings. Front cover and spine have no decoration other than gold-tooled titles. No decoration on back cover or edges. A single gold fillet along the edges of front and back pastedowns. Gilt edges on main manuscript as well as paper booklet, but these are badly faded and almost certainly predate the 1907 binding.

Centered 25mm below top edge on front cover: “LE ROMAN DELA ROSE / TESTAMENT ET CODICILE / DE JEHAN DE MEUN” Centered 65mm above bottom edge on front cover: “PARISIAN MS CIR. MCCCLXV” Centered at top of spine: “LE / ROMAN / DELA / ROSE” Centered at bottom edge of spine: “C.MCCCLXV” All of the above titles in gold tooling. Signed by binder on lower left edge of back turn-in, gold-tooled initials “K A” with binder’s stamp. Above this, written in Cockerell’s hand: “Bound by Katharine Adams of Broadway Worcestershire 1907”. Parchment pastedowns in front and back, five parchment flyleaves each in front and back.

notesStmt.note:
(Many inscriptions are badly faded, in which cases Langlois’s transcriptions in Les Manuscrits, pp. 152-53, have been consulted.)
1. Petro Gendron
On 171v: “Romanus iste Rosse pertinet Petro Gendron ex oppido Cintrey. Ille aut illa quis inveniat reddat sibi et ipse solvet vinum. P. Gerdon” In this inscription, “Petro Gendron” has been crossed out and Bertrando Garnier written above. At the bottom of 168v: “Dieu doint bonne vie a Perres Gendron qui est de grant . . .” with “qui est de grant . . .” having been erased.
2. J. Gendron
On 171r: “Le dimanche de Pasques flouris, en l'an mile ci[edge cropped] et seix, Jehanne Laberte s'en alla et print cong[edge cropped] paya de sa main” Beneath this the signature “J. Gendron” On the same leaf, the following verse:
Versus
Putain bien veytue
Souvent sort En rue
Pour son corps mo[n]trer
A putain ne chaud
Qui seus son cul sauld
Mes q[ui]lait monnoye
A cul de putain
Metez i la main
Et vo[us] trouvez merde
Beneath this, the signature ““J. Gendron”
On 171v: “Le xxieme Jors de decembre lan mil cincq cens et deulx, Il fut enterré ugne femme de g[ra]nt saigesse qui e nommee Jeha[n]ne Letexier oprion touz dieu debo[n]ayre qui li plaisse luy pardonez toutez ces fautez et cest pechiez” Below this is written “Jehan Gendron, filz de sa fille agnee, fait cessi de dieu”
3. Bertran Garnier
On 141v: “Bertran Garnier a qui je suys après la mort de dom Jehan Garnier q[ue] decebda en lan mil cinq cents” Below this, the signature “B. Garnier” At the bottom of this leaf: Je prye a dieu le roy puissant q[ue] luy plaisse si bien conduire Perres Garnier en revenant”
On 168v the signature “B. Garnier” appears beneath the following verse:
Le 15 jour daoust
1551
Ce q[ue] me faut cy lire
et tant y ennuyer
cest pour ester deliver
damours et levyter
On 170v at the end of “Le Codicille,” the signature “B. Garnier” appears beneath the following verse:
Le 19 jour daoust 1551
Jay cy tant leu et veu le estes
Que damours je suys delivré
Et pour myeulx faire ses prestre
Sil playst a dieu que j'ay pryé
On 171r: “Bertan Garnier”
4. At the end of the paper booklet, fol. 181r, a coat of arms containing a hunting horn, and to the right of the coat of arms a motto reading “SECRE E LOYAL” (Langlois transcribes this as “SECRE F LOYAL, suggesting that the F is a malformed E). The coat of arms at the bottom of fol. 1r may be the same as that at 181r; it also contains a hunting horn, and appears later than the rest of the decoration of the Roman de la Rose. Vinework has been erased to accommodate the coat of arms. Langlois notes that the motto “Secret et Loyal” is used by two families, Cabilliau of Brabant and Butkens of Belgium, but that the coat of arms belongs to neither (p. 153 n. 2)
5. Thomas Crofts
A note in Cockerell's hand on the first flyleaf states that the manuscript was “Part of lot 8299 in the sale by Paterson of King St. Covent Garden of the Library of Thomas Crofts, M.A., Chancellor of the Diocese of Peterborough, April-May 1783”
6. Sydney Cockerell
Purchased March 16, 1907 by Sydney Cockerell. His inscription from the first flyleaf:
“I bought this book at Sotheby's. The name of the owner did not appear but Dr Warner tells me that he was a Captain Douglas, and that he brought the book to show him at the British Museum. It was rebound for me by Miss Adams of Broadway in red pigskin. It had no cover when I bought it, Mar 16, 1907, lot 382.
The date is about 1365, the date of the Coronation book of Charles V, Tiber. B. viii, in which, as well as in Mr Yates Thompson’s Vincent of Beauvais of Jean Duke of Berry (vol 1), sleeves with long pendant lappets may be seen. The miniatures in this MS are perhaps by the same hand as those in the second part of an Historic Universelle, no. 61 in Vol VI of the Firmin-Didot Catalogue, in which four miniatures are reproduced.”
On the same flyleaf is the inscription “Sydney C. Cockerell / Richmond Surrey / Mar. 16, 1907”
On the front pastedown, in Cockerell's hand: “This manuscript is described by Prof. Ernest Langlois in his “Les manuscrits de Roman de la Rose” (Lille, 1910) pp. 152-4, 253-4, 422 &c.” 7. The manuscript was sold by Cockerell to Pierre Berès on February 18, 1957.
8. Sold by Pierre Berès to Gérard de Berny in 1958, whose bookplate is found on the front pastedown.
In addition, the names “Roullet” and Macé Bancheu” appear on fol. 141r, and “Jehanne le???...” on the top of 146v, the latter being cropped.
Written in pencil, top left inside cover: “8265” In pencil on first flyleaf near gutter: “97/16”

note.p:
1. Roman de la Rose, Guillaume de Lorris and Jean de Meun, fols. 1r-141r
2. Testament, Jean de Meun, 142r-170r
3. “Le Codicille,” Jean de Meun, 170r-170v
4. 17th-c. poem on alchemy, 172r-181r
Roman de la Rose has lacunae at Lecoy lines 377-617, 1017-1133, 1815-1944, and 10592-10718 due to loss of leaves (see collation above)

This manuscript was formerly bound with Le Jeu des échecs moralisé (University of Chicago 392), but in 1907 Cockerell had them bound separately in matching bindings by Katharine Adams. Le Jeu des échecs moralisé was purchased by the University of Chicago in 1931; the two manuscripts were reunited when the Roman de la Rose manuscript was acquired by the University in 2007.
